In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can write a function to wrap text at a specified width by using the built-in `split` function to split the text into words and then recombining them with newlines inserted when the line length exceeds the maximum width. Here's how you could implement such a function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    lines = Vector{String}()
    current_line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = ""
        end
        current_line *= " " * word
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)
    return join(lines, "\n")
end
```

This function takes a `String` as input and an optional argument `text_width` which specifies the maximum number of characters per line. It then splits the text into words and builds a new string with each word on a new line if it would exceed the specified width when added to the current line.

Here's an example of how you might use this function:

```julia
text = "Hello there! This is some very long text that I want to wrap into multiple lines."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, text_width=20)
println(wrapped_text)
# Output:
# Hello there! This is some
# very long text that I want
# to wrap into multiple lines.
```

In this example, the `wrap_string` function breaks the input text into lines with a maximum width of 20 characters per line.
